content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" and imposes limitations on the height of buildings in the District of Columbia. The Act, known as the "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994," sets restrictions on building heights in DC. It includes provisions on using street width to determine maximum building height and limitations on the size and height of roof structures. The "District of Columbia Building Heights Act of 1994" allows for taller roof structures for non-human occupancy if approved by the Mayor, with fireproofing requirements and setback regulations. The Mayor can waive these requirements if found to be overly restrictive or impractical without interfering with the Act's purpose or neighboring buildings' light and air exposure. SEC. 3. National Capital Planning Commission's authority to enforce building height limitations has been increased. The National Capital Planning Commission now requires approval for roof structures exceeding general limitations in the District of Columbia. This amendment includes the Commission in the approval process alongside the Mayor. The amendment allows the National Capital Planning Commission to approve the height of roof structures in the District of Columbia within 45 days of submission. The amendments made by this Act will apply to buildings and structures in the District of Columbia for which building permits are issued on or after March 23, 1994.
